news_header: The 2024 Nobel Prize in Economics was awarded to Daron Acemoglu, Simon Johnson, and James A. Robinson for their research on the factors influencing the success and failure of countries.
news_text: On Monday, the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences announced that Daron Acemoglu, Simon Johnson, and James A. Robinson received the 2024 Nobel Prize in Economics for their influential studies on why some nations thrive while others do not. The award, worth 11 million Swedish kronor (approximately $1 million), highlights the significance of societal institutions in economic prosperity. Acemoglu and Johnson, professors at MIT, along with Robinson from the University of Chicago, recently published 'Why Nations Fail,' exploring wealth inequality and the impact of technology on job creation. The economics prize, established in 1968, has been awarded 55 times to 93 laureates, with the U.S. leading in recipients. The award ceremony will take place on December 10, coinciding with the anniversary of Alfred Nobel's death.
